div.fw: The Reues tale · And þᵉ Cookꝭes prologe
div.l: Of Alen ⁊and of Iohn that bette hym wele
His wyf is swyued and his doughter als
Loo such it is a meller to be fals
And þerfore this ꝓprouerbe is seyd full sothe
Hym dar noȝt wyf weene wele · that yuell doth
A gylour shall hym self begyled be
And god that sitteth highe in mageste
Saue all this cumpany grete ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quyt the myller my tale
The cok of london̄ while the Refe spake
For ioy hym þoght he clawed hym on the bake
Ha ha qᵈuod he for cristes passion
This meller hath a sharp conclusion
Vppon his argument of herbigage
Wele seid salamon in his langage
Ne bryng not eủery man̄ in to thyn hous
For herberyng by nyght is ꝑperylous
Wele aught a man̄ avysed for to be
Whom that he brought in to his priuety
I pray to god so ȝif me sorw ⁊and care
Yf euer syn I hight hogge of ware
Herd y a meller better y sette on werk
He had a iape of malice in the derk
And therfore yf ȝe vochesaue to here
But god forbede that we stynt here
A tale of me that am a poure man̄
I will ȝow telle as wele as eủery I can̄
A litell Iape that fille in oure Cite
Oure ost ansuerd and seyd I gᵃraunte hit the
Now telle on Roger loke that hit be goode
For many a past hast þow leten̄ blode
And mony a Iakke at Douer hast þow solde
That hath twyes and twyes cold
